problem: Express the energy and wavelength of the photon after the second collision as a function of the wavelength of the photon before the collision $\lambda_0$, the scattering angle $\theta$ and $\Lambda=h /\left(m_0 \cdot c\right)$.
solution: The conservation law for moments in the scattering process gives $ \left\{\begin{array}{l} \frac{h}{\lambda_0}=\frac{h}{\lambda_f} \cos \theta+m \cdot v_{2 e} \cdot \cos \beta \\ \frac{h}{\lambda_f} \sin \theta-m \cdot v_{2 e} \cdot \sin \beta=0 \end{array}\right. $  To eliminate the unknown angle $\beta$, one must square and then add equations ( 24) That is $ \left\{\begin{array}{l} \left(\frac{h}{\lambda_0}-\frac{h}{\lambda_f} \cos \theta\right)^2=\left(m \cdot v_{2 e} \cdot \cos \beta\right)^2 \\ \left(\frac{h}{\lambda_f} \sin \theta\right)^2=\left(m \cdot v_{2 e} \cdot \sin \beta\right)^2 \end{array}\right. $ and $ \left(\frac{h}{\lambda_f}\right)^2+\left(\frac{h}{\lambda_0}\right)^2-\frac{2 \cdot h^2}{\lambda_0 \cdot \lambda_f} \cos \theta=\left(m \cdot v_{2 e}\right)^2 $ or $ \frac{h^2 \cdot c^2}{\lambda_f^2}+\frac{h^2 \cdot c^2}{\lambda_0^2}-\frac{2 \cdot h^2 \cdot c^2}{\lambda_0 \cdot \lambda_f} \cos \theta=m^2 \cdot c^2 \cdot v_{2 e}^2 $  The conservation law for energies in the second scattering process gives $ \frac{h \cdot c}{\lambda_0}+m_0 \cdot c^2=\frac{h \cdot c}{\lambda_f}+m \cdot c^2 $ or $ h^2 \cdot c^2 \cdot\left(\frac{1}{\lambda_f}-\frac{1}{\lambda_0}\right)^2+m_0^2 \cdot c^4+2 h \cdot c^3 \cdot m_0 \cdot\left(\frac{1}{\lambda_f}-\frac{1}{\lambda_0}\right)=\frac{m_0^2 \cdot c^4}{1-\left(v_{2 e} / c\right)^2} $  Subtracting (27) from (29), one obtains $ +\frac{2 \cdot h^2 \cdot c^2}{\lambda_0 \cdot \lambda_f} \cos \theta-\frac{2 \cdot h^2 \cdot c^2}{\lambda_0 \cdot \lambda_f}+2 h \cdot c^3 \cdot m_0 \cdot\left(\frac{1}{\lambda_f}-\frac{1}{\lambda_0}\right)=0 $ that is $ \left\{\begin{array}{l} \frac{h}{m_0 \cdot c} \cdot(1-\cos \theta)=\lambda_f-\lambda_0 \\ \lambda_f-\lambda_0=\Lambda \cdot(1-\cos \theta) \end{array}\right. $  Concluding $ \left\{\begin{array}{l} \lambda_f>\lambda_0 \\ E_f<E_0 \end{array}\right. $  Comparing (31) written as $ \lambda_f=\lambda_0+\Lambda \cdot(1-\cos \theta) $ and (22) written as $ \lambda_i=\lambda_0+\Lambda \cdot(1-\cos \theta) $ results in $ \lambda_1=\lambda $

problem: Express the kinetic energy $\left(T_2=E_{2 e}-E_{0 e}\right)$ and momentum $p_{2 e}$ of the electron after the second collision as a function of the photon wavelengths after the collision $\lambda_f, m_0, c$ and $h$.
solution: aking into account (26), the moment of the electron after the second collision is $ p_{2 e}=h \sqrt{\frac{1}{\lambda_f^2}+\frac{1}{\lambda_0^2}-\frac{2 \cdot \cos \theta}{\lambda_f \cdot \lambda_0}} $  Or, considering (33), the moment can be rewritten as $ p_{2 e}=h \sqrt{\frac{1}{\lambda_f^2}+\frac{1}{\left(\lambda_f-\Lambda(1-\cos \theta)\right)^2}-\frac{2 \cdot \cos \theta}{\lambda_f \cdot\left(\lambda_f-\Lambda(1-\cos \theta)\right)}} $  The expression of the de Broglie wavelength of the second electron after scattering is $ \lambda_{2 e}=1 /\left(\sqrt{\frac{1}{\lambda_f^2}+\frac{1}{\left(\lambda_f-\Lambda(1-\cos \theta)\right)^2}-\frac{2 \cdot \cos \theta}{\lambda_f \cdot\left(\lambda_f-\Lambda(1-\cos \theta)\right)}}\right) $  From (28) results $ \frac{h \cdot c}{\lambda_0}=\frac{h \cdot c}{\lambda_f}+T_2 $ that is $ T_2=h \cdot c \cdot\left(\frac{1}{\lambda_0}-\frac{1}{\lambda_f}\right) $

problem: Using the values of the given physical constants and numerical values of $\lambda_f$ and $\theta$ determine the expressions and numerical values for: the De Broglie wavelength of the initial electron;
solution: The relation (13) can be written as $ p_{1 \mathrm{e}}=h \sqrt{\frac{1}{\lambda_i^2}+\frac{1}{\lambda_0^2}-\frac{2 \cdot \cos \theta}{\lambda_i \cdot \lambda_0}} $ or, considering (34) and (35) $ p_{1 e}=h \sqrt{\frac{1}{\lambda_f^2}+\frac{1}{\left(\lambda_f-\Lambda(1-\cos \theta)\right)^2}-\frac{2 \cdot \cos \theta}{\lambda_f \cdot\left(\lambda_f-\Lambda(1-\cos \theta)\right)}} $ so that the expression of the de Broglie wavelength of the first electron before scattering is $ \lambda_{1 e}=1 /\left(\sqrt{\frac{1}{\lambda_f^2}+\frac{1}{\left(\lambda_f-\Lambda(1-\cos \theta)\right)^2}-\frac{2 \cdot \cos \theta}{\lambda_f \cdot\left(\lambda_f-\Lambda(1-\cos \theta)\right)}}\right) $  In the condition of the problem (43) becomes $ \lambda_{1 e}=1 /\left(\sqrt{\frac{1}{\lambda_f^2}+\frac{1}{\left(\lambda_f-\frac{\Lambda}{2}\right)^2}-\frac{1}{\lambda_f \cdot\left(\lambda_f-\frac{\Lambda}{2}\right)}}\right) $  Because the value of $\lambda_f$ and $\Lambda$ are known as $ \left\{\begin{array}{l} \lambda_f=\lambda_i=1,25 \times 10^{-10} \mathrm{~m} \\ \Lambda=\frac{6,6 \times 10^{-34}}{9,1 \times 10^{-31} \cdot 3,0 \times 10^8} \mathrm{~m}=2,41 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{~m}=0,02 \times 10^{-10} \mathrm{~m} \end{array}\right. $  From (33) results that $ \lambda_0=\lambda_f-\Lambda \cdot(1-\cos \theta)=\lambda_f-\frac{\Lambda}{2} $ or $ \lambda_0=1,24 \times 10^{-10} \mathrm{~m} $  The numerical value of the de Broglie wavelength of the first electron before scattering is $ \lambda_{1 e}=10^{-10} /\left(\sqrt{\frac{1}{1,25^2}+\frac{1}{1,24^2}-\frac{1}{1,25 \times 1,24}}\right) m \cong 1,25 \times 10^{-10} \mathrm{~m} $  Evidently the de Broglie wavelength $\lambda_{2 e}$ for the second electron after the scattering is the same $ \lambda_{1 e}=\lambda_{2 e} $

problem: the energy and frequency of the initial photon;
solution: Because $\lambda_f=\lambda_i$ the energy of the first photon before the first scattering has the following expression $ E_i=\frac{h \cdot c}{\lambda_i}=\frac{h \cdot c}{\lambda_f} $  Its numerical value is $ E_i=\frac{h \cdot c}{\lambda_i}=\frac{6,6 \times 10^{-34} \cdot 3,0 \times 10^8}{1,25 \times 10^{-10}} \cong 1,58 \times 10^{-15} \mathrm{~J}=9,9 \mathrm{KeV} $  The frequency $f_i$ of the first photon before the first scattering has the following expression $ f_i=\frac{c}{\lambda_i}=\frac{c}{\lambda_f} $  Its numerical value is $ f_i=\frac{3 \times 10^8}{1,25 \times 10^{-10}} \cong 2,4 \times 10^{18} \mathrm{~Hz} $

problem: the speed of the second electron after collision;
solution: From (40) written as $ T_2=T_1=m \cdot c^2-m_0 \cdot c^2=h \cdot c \cdot\left(\frac{1}{\lambda_0}-\frac{1}{\lambda_f}\right) $ results $ m=m_0+\frac{h}{c} \cdot\left(\frac{1}{\lambda_f-(\Lambda / 2)}-\frac{1}{\lambda_f}\right) \cong m_0+\frac{h}{c} \cdot \frac{\Lambda}{2 \lambda_f^2}=m_0 \cdot\left(1+\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{h}{m_0 \cdot c \cdot \lambda_f}\right)^2\right) $  Its numerical value is $ m \cong m_0 $  Consequently, the speed of the second electron after the collision $v_{2 e}$ has the following expression $ v_{2 e}=\frac{h}{\lambda_f \cdot m} \approx \frac{h}{\lambda_f \cdot m_0} $  Its numerical value is $ v_{2 e} \approx 5,8 \times 10^6 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}=0,019 \cdot \mathrm{c} $

problem: the variation of the photon wavelength after each collision process.
solution: $ \lambda_i-\lambda_0=\lambda_f-\lambda_0=\frac{\Lambda}{2} $  The numerical value of the variation of wavelength is $\frac{\Lambda}{2} \cong 0,01 \times 10^{-10} \mathrm{~m}$

problem: Star Ship Enterprise has on each of the two warp engines a succession of five collinear, equidistant, numbered, beacons as shown in ###img_1### (for the propeller on right side). When traveling, SS Enterprise moves with constant speed $\vec{v}$ so that, for the questions that follow, beacons located on a propeller are always on the same line that is $O x$ axis of the coordinate system. In the situation room of another spacecraft which is at rest and which oversees the SS Enterprise, are analyzed the images of line of beacons. The images are taken by a camera with the aperture located at the point $(0, d)$ - in the orthogonal coordinate system shown in the inset in ###img_1### above. An image of line of beacons is produced by light rays that arrive simultaneously at camera aperture that opens for a short time. On a picture of SS Enterprise at rest, the length of line of beacons is $L$. In the problem, the beacons can be considered as points.  The speed of light is $c=3,00 \times 10^8 \mathrm{~m} \cdot \mathrm{s}^{-1}$. Employ the quantities $\beta=v / c$ and $\gamma=1 / \sqrt{1-\beta^2}$, if they help to simplify your result. The actual position is the position in the frame in which the camera is at rest. Next, the camera remains stationary in the point $(0, d)$ and the SS Enterprise is moving at velocity $\vec{v}$ on $O x$ direction. In an image provided by the camera described above is observed that one of the bright beacons is placed in the position $x_i$. Determine the expression for the actual position of the bright beacon when the image is formed in the camera.
solution: ###img_1### The image appearing in the camera is due to light rays arriving at the same moment and not to light rays leaving simultaneously. For this reason, the difference between the apparent image of a point on the beacon line and the current position, at the time when the image is formed, of the point on the beacon line appears. A beacon, located in the position denoted by $x_i$ appears on the image from the darkroom if the light coming from it has left before the moment of taking the image with the time $T$ having the expression $T=\frac{\sqrt{d^2+x_i^2}}{c}$ In the time it takes for the light to reach the camera obscura from the beacon, the beacon has moved a distance $v \cdot T$ so that the "current position" of the beacon at the time its image is taken is $ x=x_i+v \cdot T =x_i+\frac{v}{c} \sqrt{d^2+x_i^2}=x_i+\beta \cdot \sqrt{d^2+x_i^2} $ The beacon that was in position $x_i$ appears on image when in position $x$.

problem: Find also the corresponding inverse relation, that is the expression of $x_i$ in terms of $x, d, L, v$ and $c$.
solution: By squaring the above relation, it successively results $ \left\{\begin{array}{l} x^2-2 x \cdot x_i+x_i^2=\beta^2 \cdot d^2+\beta ^2 \cdot x_i^2 \\ \left(1-\beta^2\right) x_i^2-2 x \cdot x_i+\left(x^2-\beta^2 \cdot d^2\right)= 0 \\ \left(1-\beta^2\right) x_i^2-2 x \cdot x_i+\left(x^2-d^2+\left(1-\beta^2\right) \cdot d ^2\right)=0 \\ \frac{x_i^2}{\gamma^2}-2 x \cdot x_i+\left(x^2-d^2+\frac{d^2}{\gamma^ 2}\right)=0 \end{array}\right. $ Appropriately, $ \left\{\begin{array}{l} x_i=\gamma^2\left(x \pm \sqrt{x^2-\frac{1}{\gamma^2}\left(x ^2-\beta^2 \cdot d^2\right)}\right) \\ x_i=\gamma^2\left(x \pm \frac{1}{\gamma} \sqrt{\beta^2 \ cdot d^2-\left(1-\gamma^2\right) \cdot x^2}\right) \end{array}\right. $ Because $ 1-\gamma^2=1-\frac{1}{1-\beta^2}=\frac{-\beta^2}{1-\beta^2}=-\beta^2 \ cdot \gamma^2 $ from the last relation in (5) results $ \left\{\begin{array}{l} x_i=\gamma^2\left(x \pm \frac{\beta}{\gamma} \ sqrt{d^2+\gamma^2 \cdot x^2}\right) \\ x_i=\gamma\left(\gamma \cdot x \pm \beta \sqrt{d^2+\gamma^2 \cdot x^2}\right) \end{array}\right. $ As the origin of the moving axis approaches the projection, the natural selection of the sign in the above expressions leads to $ \boldsymbol{x}_i=\gamma\left(\gamma \cdot \boldsymbol{x}-\beta \ cdot \sqrt{\boldsymbol{d}^2+\gamma^2 \cdot \boldsymbol{x}^2}\right) $ The beacon whose image appears in position $x_i$ is located at the moment of formation of the image in position $x $.

problem: The camera takes a picture of the instant when the actual position of the center of beacons line is at some $x_0$ point. 2.a. Determine the expression for the apparent length of the beacons line on this picture.
solution: Since the beacons move with the speed $\vec{v}$ its length is - due to the Lorentz contraction - $L / \gamma$. When the camera obscura forms the image of the line of beacons with the center at the point $x_0$, the beacons at the ends respectively have the positions $ x_{\text {face }}=x_{+}=x_0+\frac{L}{2 \gamma } $ and $ x_{\text {back }}=x_{-}=x_0-\frac{L}{2 \gamma} $ The images of the ends $x_{i, \pm}$ will be formed by the camera obscura "as and how" would have been in positions $ x_{i, \pm}=\gamma\left(\gamma \cdot x_0 \pm \frac{L}{2}\right)-\beta \cdot \gamma \ sqrt{d^2+\left(\gamma \cdot x_0 \pm \frac{L}{2}\right)^2} $ In the above relation, the expressions of the positions of the ends of the beacon line and the relation ( 8). The apparent length of the beacon line, $L_i$, is the difference of the apparent positions of the ends, i.e. $L_i\left(x_0\right)=x_{i,+}-x_{i,-}$ $ L_i\left(x_0\right )=\gamma \cdot L-\beta \cdot \gamma \sqrt{d^2+\left(\gamma \cdot x_0+\frac{L}{2}\right)^2}+\beta \cdot \gamma \sqrt{d^2+\left(\gamma \cdot x_0-\frac{L}{2}\right)^2} $

problem: Indicate - using a mathematical expression - how the apparent length of beacons line changes with time, when SS Enterprise moves along the Ox axe. The space ship comes from far away, passes through the origin of the system and then receding far away.
solution: Seen as a function of $x_0$, the polynomial expression of degree 2 $ F_1=\left(\gamma \cdot x_0+\frac{L}{2}\right)^2+d^2 $ has a minimum with the value $d^ 2$ for $ x_0=-\frac{L}{2 \gamma} $ For values of the variable $x_0, x_0 \geq-\frac{L}{2 \gamma}$ the function $F_1$ is monotonically increasing. Accordingly, the expression $ E_1=-\beta \cdot \gamma \sqrt{F_1} $ is monotonically increasing up to $x_0=-\frac{L}{2 \gamma}$ , then monotonically decreasing and has a maximum of $ E_{1, \max }=E_1\left(x_0=-\frac{L}{2 \gamma}\right)=-\beta \gamma d $ For $ x_0=\frac{L}{2 \gamma} \\ E_1\left(x_0=\frac{L}{2 \gamma}\right)=-\beta \cdot \gamma \sqrt{d^2+ L^2} $ Graphically, the dependence $E_1\left(x_0\right)$ has the appearance shown in ###img_1###. Analogously, seen as a function of $x_0$ the polynomial expression of degree 2 $ F_2=\left(\gamma \cdot x_0-\frac{L}{2}\right)^2+d^2 $ has a minimum with the value $ d^2$ for $ x_0=\frac{L}{2 \gamma} $ For values of the variable $x_0, x_0 \geq \frac{L}{2 \gamma}$ the function $F_2$ is monotonically increasing. Accordingly, the expression $ E_2=\beta \cdot \gamma \sqrt{F_2} $ is monotonically decreasing up to $x_0=\frac{L}{2 \gamma}$ , then monotonically increasing and has a minimum in the value of $ E_ {2, \text { min im }}=E_2\left(x_0=\frac{L}{2 \gamma}\right)=\beta \gamma d $ For $ x_0=-\frac{L}{2 \ gamma} $ $ E_2\left(x_0=-\frac{L}{2 \gamma}\right)=\beta \cdot \gamma \sqrt{d^2+L^2} $ Graphically, the dependence $E_2\left(x_0\ right)$ has the appearance shown in ###img_1###. The expression $ \left\{\begin{array}{l} E=E_1+E_2=\gamma \beta\left(\sqrt{F_2}-\sqrt{\left.F_1 \right)}\right. \\ E=\gamma \beta \frac{F_2-F_1}{\left(\sqrt{F_2}+\sqrt{F_1}\right)}=\frac{\left(\gamma \cdot x_0-\frac{ L}{2}\right)^2+d^2-\left(\left(\gamma \cdot x_0+\frac{L}{2}\right)^2+d^2\right)}{\sqrt {\left(\gamma \cdot x_0-\frac{L}{2}\right)^2+d^2}+\sqrt{\left(\gamma \cdot x_0+\frac{L}{2}\right )^2+d^2}} \\ E=\gamma \beta \frac{-2}{\sqrt{\left(\gamma \cdot x_0-\frac{L}{2}\right)^2+ d^2}+\sqrt{\left(\gamma \cdot x_0+\frac{L}{2}\right)^2+d^2}} \gamma \cdot x_0 \end{array}\right. $ is monotonically decreasing - as seen in the image in ###img_1###. The last relationship in the above set can also be written in the form $ E=\frac{-2 \gamma^2 \cdot \beta \cdot L}{\sqrt {\left(\gamma-\frac{L}{2 x_0}\right)^2+\left(\frac{d}{x_0}\right)^2}+\sqrt{\left(\gamma+\frac {L}{2 x_0}\right)^2+\left(\frac{d}{x_0}\right)^2}} \cdot \frac{x_0}{\left|x_0\right|} $ For values negatives of the variable $x_0$, the above expression is written $ E_{-}=\frac{2 \gamma^2 \cdot \beta \cdot L}{\sqrt{\left(\gamma-\frac{L} {2 x_0}\right)^2+\left(\frac{d}{x_0}\right)^2}+\sqrt{\left(\gamma+\frac{L}{2 x_0}\right)^2 +\left(\frac{d}{x_0}\right)^2}} $ Obviously, if $x_0$ evolves monotonically increasing between $-\infty$ and 0, i.e. for $-\infty<x_0<0$, the expression from (27) also evolves monotonically but decreasing between the values $ E_{-}(-\infty)=\frac{\gamma^2 \cdot \beta \cdot L}{\sqrt{\gamma^2}}=\ gamma \cdot \beta \cdot L $ and $ E_{-}(0)=0 $ For positive values of the variable $x_0$, expression (26) is written $ E_{+}=\frac{-2 \gamma^ 2 \cdot \beta \cdot L}{\sqrt{\left(\gamma-\frac{L}{2 x_0}\right)^2+\left(\frac{d}{x_0}\right)^2 }+\sqrt{\left(\gamma+\frac{L}{2 x_0}\right)^2+\left(\frac{d}{x_0}\right)^2}} $ If $x_0$ evolves monotonically increasing between 0 and $\infty$ i.e. if $0<x_0<\infty$, the expression in (30) also evolves monotonically, but decreasing between $ E_{+}(0)=0 \\ \text { and } \\ E_{+}(\infty)=-\gamma \cdot \beta \cdot L $ The analytical study of the apparent length. $ L_i\left(x_0\right)=\gamma \cdot L+E $ shows - also - that it evolves monotonically decreasing when $x_0$ increases. Therefore, the apparent length of the beacon line decreases all the time. The statement above represents the answer to task 2.b.

problem: One of the pictures taken by the camera shows both ends of beacons line at the same distance from the aperture of camera. Determine the expression for the apparent length of beacons line on this picture.
solution: If in the image taken by the camera obscura the ends of the line of beacons are at the same distance from the aperture of the camera obscura, it means that the light coming from both ends of the line of beacons travels equal paths to reach the aperture of the camera in equal time intervals. The light forming the image simultaneously departed from the ends of the line of beacons. The apparent length of the beacon line is in these conditions the length of the moving beacon line - i.e. $\frac{L}{\gamma}$. The answer to question 3.a. regarding the apparent length of the beacon line that appears in the symmetric image is therefore $ L_{i, \text { symmetric }}=\frac{L}{\gamma} $ The expression in relation (34) ${ }^*$

problem: Determine the expression for the actual position of the middle beacons at the time when this picture is taken.
solution: The images of the heads are - according to the statement - symmetrical. This returns to $ x_{i,+}=-x_{i,-} $ i.e. $ x_{i,+}+x_{i,-}=0 $ Taking into account (10) the above relation becomes $ 0 =x_{i,+}+x_{i,-}=2 \gamma^2 \cdot x_0-\beta \cdot \gamma \sqrt{d^2+\left(\gamma \cdot x_0+\frac{L} {2}\right)^2}-\beta \cdot \gamma \sqrt{d^2+\left(\gamma \cdot x_0-\frac{L}{2}\right)^2} $ Also writing the length apparent value of the beacon line for the analyzed situation $ \left\{\begin{array}{l} \frac{L}{\gamma}=x_{i,+}-x_{i,-}=L_i\left(x_0 \right) \\ \frac{L}{\gamma}=\gamma \cdot L-\beta \cdot \gamma \sqrt{d^2+\left(\gamma \cdot x_0+\frac{L}{2} \right)^2}+\beta \cdot \gamma \sqrt{d^2+\left(\gamma \cdot x_0-\frac{L}{2}\right)^2} \end{array}\right . $ and adding the relations above results in $ \left\{\begin{array}{l} \frac{L}{\gamma}=2 \gamma^2 \cdot x_0+\gamma \cdot L-2 \beta \cdot \gamma \sqrt{d^2+\left(\gamma \cdot x_0+\frac{L}{2}\right)^2} \\ \frac{2 \gamma^2 \cdot x_0+\gamma \cdot L- \frac{L}{\gamma}}{2 \beta \cdot \gamma}=\sqrt{d^2+\left(\gamma \cdot x_0+\frac{L}{2}\right)^2} \ \ \sqrt{d^2+\left(\gamma \cdot x_0+\frac{L}{2}\right)^2}=\frac{x_0 \cdot \gamma}{\beta}+\frac{L\ left(\gamma^2-1\right)}{2 \beta \cdot \gamma^2}=\frac{x_0 \cdot \gamma}{\beta}+\frac{L \cdot \beta}{2} \end{array}\right. $ Therefore $ \sqrt{d^2+\left(\gamma \cdot x_0+\frac{L}{2}\right)^2}=\frac{x_0 \cdot \gamma}{\beta}+\frac{L \ cdot \beta}{2} $ Subtracting (36) from (37) results $ \sqrt{d^2+\left(\gamma \cdot x_0-\frac{L}{2}\right)^2}=\ frac{x_0 \cdot \gamma}{\beta}-\frac{L \cdot \beta}{2} $ From any of the last two relations, the value of the position of the middle of the beacon line can be extracted. problem: A body (treated as a material point) with the mass $m$ is kept at rest on a slope (###img_1###) with a constant inclination on its whole length. When released, the body starts to slide towards the base of the slope and continues to move to the right on the horizontal plane. The connection region between the slope and the horizontal plane is smooth, such that the speed of the body does not change, only the direction of its velocity. The starting point is at a height $h$ above the horizontal plane and the value of the gravitational acceleration is constant and known, $g$. Friction is neglected everywhere. Derive the mathematical expression for the speed $v_0$ of the body on the horizontal plane.
solution: In the absence of friction, mechanical energy is conserved. Taking the zero level for the gravitational potential energy on the horizontal plane, at the starting point the body has only potential energy, $m g h$, and on the horizontal plane only kinetic energy, $\frac{m v_0^2}{2}$. So, $ m g h=\frac{m v_0^2}{2}, $ leading to $ v_0=\sqrt{2 g h}.$

problem: Consider now the same process, but seen from a reference system moving to the right with the constant speed $v_0$ relative to the ground (the slope and the horizontal plane). In this reference system the final energy of the body is zero, while its initial energy is positive. Where did the energy "disappeared"? Give a detailed quantitative analysis of the missing energy.
solution: Taking into account the free body diagram from ###img_1###, the theorem of variation for the kinetic energy is $ \Delta E_c=L_{m g}+L_N . $  Since the initial speed of the body is $v_0$ and its final speed is zero, the variation of its kinetic energy is $ \Delta E_c=0-\frac{m v_0^2}{2}=-\frac{m v_0^2}{2}=-m g h, $ while the work done by the body's weight is $ L_{m g}=mgh. $ Since $\vec{v}_r$ is not perpendicular on $\vec{N}$ ###img_2###, then the work done by $ N=m g \cos \alpha $ on the descending part of the slope, which makes an angle $\alpha$ with the horizontal plane, is $ d L_{1 N}=\vec{N} \cdot \vec{v}_r d t=-N v_0 d t \sin \alpha=-m g v_0 d t \sin \alpha \cos \alpha, $ or, $ L_{1 N}=-m g v_0 \tau_1 \sin \alpha \cos \alpha, $ where $\tau_1$ is the descending time, found from projecting the equation of motion for the body on the vertical axis. $ m a_y=m g-N \cos \alpha=m g-m g \cos ^2 \alpha=m g \sin ^2 \alpha . $  So, $ a_y=g \sin ^2 \alpha, $ hence $ \tau_1=\sqrt{\frac{2 h}{a_y}}=\frac{1}{\sin \alpha} \sqrt{\frac{2 h}{g}} . $  Consequently, $ L_{1 N}=-m g v_0 \sqrt{\frac{2 h}{g}} \cos \alpha=-m g \sqrt{2 g h} \sqrt{\frac{2 h}{g}} \cos \alpha=-2 m g h \cos \alpha . $ On the connection region between the slope and the horizontal plane the body's speed is $v_0$, constant in magnitude, but not in orientation. As a result ###img_3###, the work done by $\vec{N}$ on this part of the trajectory is $ d L_{2 N}=\vec{N} \cdot \vec{v}_r d t=-N v_0 d t \sin \beta . $  Projecting on the horizontal axis the mathematical expression of the theorem of momentum variation, $ d p_x=N_x d t=N d t \sin \beta $  So, $ d L_{2 N}=-v_0 d p_x $  For the entire connection region, $ L_{2 N}=-v_0 \Delta p_x=-v_0 m\left(v_0-v_0 \cos \alpha\right)=-m v_0^2(1-\cos \alpha)=-2 m g h(1-\cos \alpha) . $  In conclusion, $ L_N=L_{1 N}+L_{2 N}=-2 m g h, $ so, the theorem of kinetic energy variation also holds in the moving inertial system.

problem: The energy transferred by an electromagnetic wave per unit of time per unit of surface is called Poynting vector and has the mathematical form $ \vec{S}=\frac{1}{\mu_0} \vec{E} \times \vec{B} $ where $\mu_0$ is the magnetic permeability of vacuum. The electric permittivity of vacuum, $\varepsilon_0$, is also known. Derive the volume density of the linear momentum of an electromagnetic wave, $p_V$. Express your result in vector form $\left(\vec{p}_V\right)$.
solution: Since an electromagnetic wave may be considered to be made of photons, then their momentum is $ \delta p=\frac{\delta W}{c}=\frac{S \delta A \delta t}{c}, $ where $c$ is light speed in vacuum. In these conditions, the volume density of the linear momentum is $ p_V=\frac{\delta p}{\delta V}=\frac{S \delta A \delta t}{c \delta A \delta l}=\frac{S}{c \frac{\delta l}{\delta t}}=\frac{S}{c^2} . $  In vector form, $ \vec{p}_V=\frac{1}{c^2 \mu_0} \vec{E} \times \vec{B}=\varepsilon_0 \vec{E} \times \vec{B} $

problem: In ###img_1### there are two long, coaxial cylindrical shells of length $l$. The inner one has the radius $a$ and the electric charge $+Q$, uniformly distributed over its surface. The outer cylinder has the radius $b(b<<l)$ and the electric charge $-Q$, uniformly distributed over its surface. The cylinders are made of the same material, having the mass per unit of area equal to $\sigma$ . Coaxial with them there is a long solenoid with the radius $R(a<R<b)$, with $n$ turns per unit length, and carrying an electric current $i$. The solenoid is fixed, but the cylindrical shells can freely and independently rotate around their common axis. Initially all the parts of this system are at rest. Note: The cylindrical shells are heavy enough to neglect any magnetic field due to their rotation! When the current in the solenoid is gradually reduced to zero, the cylinders begin to rotate. Derive the mathematical expressions of the final angular velocities (magnitude and orientation) of the cylinders.
solution: The current through the solenoid produces inside it a magnetic field given by $ \vec{B}=\mu_0 n i \hat{z}, \text { for } r<R \text {. } $  When the current decreases, the magnetic field strength decreases, inducing an electric field (with the circular field lines), in accord with Faraday's law $ \vec{E} \cdot 2 \pi r \hat{\phi}=-\frac{d}{d t}(\vec{B} \cdot \vec{S}) \text {. } $  If $r<R$, then $\vec{S}=\pi r^2 \hat{z}$ and $ \vec{E}=-\frac{1}{2} \mu_0 n \frac{d i}{d t} r \hat{\phi} $ while if $r>R$, then $\vec{S}=\pi R^2 \hat{z}$ and $ \vec{E}=-\frac{1}{2} \mu_0 n \frac{d i}{d t} \frac{R^2}{r} \hat{\phi} . $  The torque on the inner cylinder is $ \vec{\tau}_a=\vec{r} \times Q \vec{E}=-\frac{1}{2} \mu_0 n Q a^2 \frac{d i}{d t} \hat{r} \times \hat{\phi}=-\frac{1}{2} \mu_0 n Q a^2 \frac{d i}{d t} \hat{z} . $  In accord with the theorem for the variation of the angular momentum, $ \vec{\tau}_a=\frac{d \vec{L}_a}{d t} $ so $ \Delta \vec{L}_a=-\frac{1}{2} \mu_0 n Q a^2 \Delta i \hat{z} $ or $ \vec{L}_a=\frac{1}{2} \mu_0 n Q a^2 i \hat{z} $  Because $ \vec{L}_a=I \vec{\omega}_a=m_a a^2 \vec{\omega}_a=2 \pi l \sigma a^3 \vec{\omega}_a $ then $ \vec{\omega}_a=\frac{\mu_0 n Q i}{4 \pi l \sigma a} \hat{z}, $  For the outer cylinder, the torque is $ \vec{\tau}_b=\vec{r} \times(-Q) \vec{E}=\frac{1}{2} \mu_0 n Q R^2 \frac{d i}{d t} \hat{r} \times \hat{\phi}=\frac{1}{2} \mu_0 n Q R^2 \frac{d i}{d t} \hat{z} . $  Using the theorem for the variation of the angular momentum, $ \vec{\tau}_b=\frac{d \vec{L}_b}{d t}, $ the variation of the angular momentum is $ \Delta \vec{L}_b=\frac{1}{2} \mu_0 n Q R^2 \Delta i \hat{z}, $ or $ \vec{L}_b=-\frac{1}{2} \mu_0 n Q R^2 i \hat{z} $  Because $ \vec{L}_b=I \vec{\omega}_b=m_b b^2 \vec{\omega}_b=2 \pi l \sigma b^3 \vec{\omega}_b, $ then $ \vec{\omega}_b=-\frac{\mu_0 n Q i R^2}{4 \pi l \sigma b^3} \hat{z}, $ which means that the outer cylinder rotates clockwise, when seen from above.

problem: Since no external force acted on the system, its angular momentum should be conserved. From where did the angular momentum "appeared"? Give a detailed quantitative analysis of this paradox.
solution: In the region between the cylinders $(a<r<b)$ there is an electric field, given by Gauss theorem $ \vec{E}=\frac{Q}{2 \pi \varepsilon_0 l} \frac{1}{r} \hat{r} . $  While there is a current through the solenoid, there will be a magnetic field inside it, so, the linear momentum density of the fields is $ \vec{p}_V=\varepsilon_0 \vec{E} \times \vec{B}=\frac{Q}{2 \pi l} \frac{1}{r} \hat{r} \times \mu_0 n i \hat{z}=-\frac{\mu_0 n i Q}{2 \pi l} \frac{1}{r} \hat{\phi} . $  The angular momentum density of the fields will be $ \vec{l}_{e m}=\vec{r} \times \vec{p}_V=-\frac{\mu_0 n i Q}{2 \pi l} \hat{r} \times \hat{\phi}=-\frac{\mu_0 n i Q}{2 \pi l} \hat{z} . $  The total angular momentum of the fields will be $ \vec{L}_{e m}=\vec{l}_{e m} \times \pi\left(R^2-a^2\right) l=-\frac{1}{2} \mu_0 n i Q\left(R^2-a^2\right) \hat{z} . $  Checking the above results, it immediately follows that $ \vec{L}_{e m}=\vec{L}_a+\vec{L}_b, $ or that the fields angular momentum is totally transformed into mechanical angular momentum of the cylinders.

problem: Instead of decreasing the current through the solenoid, the cylinders are rigidly connected with a radial spoke with negligible mass (the practical method of doing this is not of interest here). The spoke is a weak conductor in order to neglect the displacement current. Determine the total angular momentum of the cylinders in this case, as well as their angular velocity.
solution: In this case the electric field is turned off and the mechanism of transforming the angular momentum is based on the Lorentz force. So, the force acting on a segment $ d \vec{r}=d r \hat{r} $ of the spoke is $ d \vec{F}=i_1 d \vec{r} \times \vec{B}=i_1 B d r \hat{r} \times \hat{z}=i_1 B d r(-\hat{\phi})=-i_1 B d r \hat{\phi}, $ where $ i_1=\frac{d Q}{d t} $ is the current discharging the cylinders and $ \vec{B}=\left\{\begin{array}{l} \mu_0 n i \hat{z}, \text { for } a<r<R \\ \overrightarrow{0}, \text { for } r>R \end{array}\right. $ is the magnetic field produced by the solenoid. The torque on the spoke will be $ \vec{\tau}=\int_a^b \vec{r} \times d \vec{F}=-\mu_0 n i i_1\left(\int_a^R r d r\right) \hat{r} \times \hat{\phi}=-\frac{1}{2} \mu_0 n i i_1\left(R^2-a^2\right) \hat{z} . $  Since $ \vec{\tau}=\frac{d \vec{L}}{d t} $ then $ \frac{d \vec{L}}{d t}=-\frac{1}{2} \mu_0 n i \frac{d Q}{d t}\left(R^2-a^2\right) \hat{z}, $ or $ \Delta \vec{L}=-\frac{1}{2} \mu_0 n i \Delta Q\left(R^2-a^2\right) \hat{z} . $  From here, because $ \Delta \vec{L}=\vec{L}-\overrightarrow{0}=\vec{L} \text { and } \Delta Q=Q-0=Q, $ it follows that $ \vec{L}=-\frac{1}{2} \mu_0 n i Q\left(R^2-a^2\right) \hat{z}, $ in agreement with the above result for the angular momentum of the fields. Finally, the angular velocity of the cylinders is $\vec{\omega}=\frac{\vec{L}}{I_{t o t}}=-\frac{\mu_0 n i Q\left(R^2-a^2\right)}{4 \pi \sigma l\left(a^3+b^3\right)} \hat{z}$

Determine the expresion of the radius $r$ of the melon, in the conditions mentioned in this task. Express the result as function of $h, r_o$ and $r^{\prime}$.
solution: approximating the segment $A D E$ as the hypotenuse of the triangle $A O E$ (figura 2 ) $   \operatorname{tg} \theta_A=\frac{r}{h+\sqrt{r^2-r_0^2}} \\  \operatorname{tg} \theta_A=\frac{r^{\prime}}{h} \\  r^{\prime} \cdot \sqrt{r^2-r_0^2}=h \cdot\left(r-r^{\prime}\right) \\  r^2 \cdot\left(h^2-r^{\prime 2}\right)-2 \cdot r \cdot r^{\prime} \cdot h^2+r^{\prime 2} \cdot\left(h^2+r_0^2\right)=0 \\  r_{1,2}=r^{\prime} \cdot \frac{h^2 \pm \sqrt{h^2 \cdot\left(r^{\prime 2}-r_0{ }^2\right)+r^{\prime 2} \cdot r_0{ }^2}}{h^2-r^{\prime 2}}  $

problem: 4b. Determine the angular frequency expression $\omega$ of the small vertical oscillations of the melon around the equilibrium position shown in the picture in Figure 2. Express the result as function of $\rho_0, \rho, r$, of the height of the spherical cap of the melon $h_c$ and the gravitational acceleration $g$.
solution: $  V\left(h_c-\Delta h_c\right)-V\left(h_c\right)=\frac{d V}{d h_c} \cdot\left(-\Delta h_c\right) \\  \text { expression of the Archimedean force } F_A{ }^{\prime}=\left(V\left(h_c\right)-V\left(h_c-\Delta h_c\right)\right) \cdot \rho_0 \cdot g=\rho_0 \cdot g \frac{d V}{d h_c} \cdot \Delta h_c \\  F_A{ }^{\prime}=-K \cdot \Delta h_c \\  K=-\rho_0 \cdot g \frac{d V}{d h_c} \\  \frac{d V}{d h_c}=-\pi \cdot h_c \cdot\left(2 r-h_c\right) \\  \text {elasticity constant } K=\rho_0 \cdot g \pi \cdot h_c \cdot\left(2 r-h_c\right) \\  \text { watermelon mass } M=\frac{4 \pi}{3} r^3 \cdot \rho \\  \text { the pulsation of small oscillations }\left\{\begin{array}{l}\omega=\sqrt{\frac{K}{M}} \\ \omega=\sqrt{\frac{3}{4} \cdot \frac{\rho_0}{\rho} \cdot \frac{g}{r} \cdot\left[\frac{h_c}{r}\left(2-\frac{h_c}{r}\right)\right]}\end{array}\right.$

problem: 4c. Write the equation of the small vertical oscillations of the melon, if their damping is negligible. Express the result as function of elongation $\Delta h_c$ and pulsation $\omega$.
solution: the equation of small oscillations $\frac{d^2}{d t^2}\left(\Delta h_c\right)+\omega^2 \cdot \Delta h_c=0$
